Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Online Processing of Noun Phrase Ellipsis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Comprehending language seems easy; however, we know that language comprehension involves complicated cognitive processes. This seems to be harder when part of a sentence is omitted or elided, such as in "Derek's key to the boxes must be on the table and Sue's is probably on the carpet." The sentence does not say that Sue's key to the boxes is probably on the carpet, but we are still able to understand exactly that. This project focuses on one kind of elided construction, called Noun Phrase Ellipsis, in which the noun phrase (like "key to the boxes") is elided. The crucial part in understanding how this kind of structure works is to discern what kind of information can be retrieved from memory at the stage when the readers notice that something is missing. The studies proposed here aim to test longstanding questions in psycholinguistics: (1) what is the nature of memory representation; and (2) what information is retrieved from memory during active sentence processing?

By employing eye-tracking experiments, this project investigates the retrieval process in Noun Phrase Ellipsis, which we find includes detailed structural and morphological information. Pairing ellipsis constructions with agreement attraction should illuminate the process, distinguishing the observed effect from other syntactic structures. In addition, it also seeks to determine at which stage that information influences the processing of ellipsis constructions, compared to other kinds of noun anaphora. This project will enable us to identify potential sources that interfere with resolving different types of dependencies with respect to memory retrieval mechanisms. This will in turn enhance our understanding of the difficulties experienced by second language learners and those with specific language impairments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the study was to investigate the mechanisms and constraints of the antecedent retrieval mechanism in the online sentence processing of Noun Phrase Ellipsis (NPE) in comparison to other anaphoric elements. Specifically, this study aimed to investigate whether the antecedent retrieval process involves retrieval of detailed grammatical and morphological information to recover the ellipsis site by using agreement attraction paradigm as a probe. We showed that readers retrieve grammatical information associated with the antecedent when encountering the NPE-site whereas readers do not necessarily retrieve grammatical information associated with the antecedent when other anaphoric elements such as pronoun 'it' and anaphoric 'one' are encountered. When the head noun and the verb do not agree in terms of the morphological features, readers access and retrieve another noun that matches the morphological features with the verb. This leads to an illusion of grammaticality in ungrammatical conditions when the NPE-site is accessed and recovered. We further investigated what kind of information is retrieved at the gap when Wh-Filler Gap Dependencies (WhFGD) are processed. We showed that fine-grained information associated with the wh-filler such as information associated with the head and the modifier as well as the category information is retrieved at the gap position. Based on these findings, we conclude that both maintenance and retrieval components are crucial in the processing of NPE and WhFGD, and in real-time sentence processing in general. 


Last Modified: 05/19/2020
Modified by: Nayoun Kim
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The aim of the study was to investigate the mechanisms and constraints of the antecedent retrieval mechanism in the online sentence processing of Noun Phrase Ellipsis (NPE) in comparison to other anaphoric elements. Specifically, this study aimed to investigate whether the antecedent retrieval process involves retrieval of detailed grammatical and morphological information to recover the ellipsis site by using agreement attraction paradigm as a probe. We showed that readers retrieve grammatical information associated with the antecedent when encountering the NPE-site whereas readers do not necessarily retrieve grammatical information associated with the antecedent when other anaphoric elements such as pronoun 'it' and anaphoric 'one' are encountered. When the head noun and the verb do not agree in terms of the morphological features, readers access and retrieve another noun that matches the morphological features with the verb. This leads to an illusion of grammaticality in ungrammatical conditions when the NPE-site is accessed and recovered. We further investigated what kind of information is retrieved at the gap when Wh-Filler Gap Dependencies (WhFGD) are processed. We showed that fine-grained information associated with the wh-filler such as information associated with the head and the modifier as well as the category information is retrieved at the gap position. Based on these findings, we conclude that both maintenance and retrieval components are crucial in the processing of NPE and WhFGD, and in real-time sentence processing in general.
